metadata.case_name: State of Bihar v. Keeper of Bharati Press

facts.text: Respondent was the keeper of Bharati Press at Purulia.
Pamphlet under the heading 'Sangram' printed at Bharati Press and circulated in Purulia, Manbhum district.
Government of Bihar considered pamphlet contained objectionable matter under section 4(1) of Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931.
Government required press to furnish security of Rs. 2,000 under section 3(3) by 19th September 1949.
Respondent applied to High Court of Patna under section 23 on 26th September 1949 to set aside the order.
High Court Special Bench (Shearer, Ramaswami, Sarjoo Prosad JJ.) allowed application by majority on 13th October 1950; Shearer J. dissented.
High Court held pamphlet came within section 4(1) but section 4(1)(a) void under Article 19(1).
Appeal to Supreme Court under Articles 132(1) and 134(1)(c).

legal_issues.text: Whether the pamphlet contained words or signs or visible representations under section 4(1)(a) of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act.
Whether section 4(1)(a) of the Act is repugnant to Article 19(1) and void under Article 13.

petitioner_arguments.text: Pamphlet contained matter inciting or encouraging commission of murder or cognizable offence involving violence under section 4(1)(a).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, s.4(1)(a)

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 4(1)(a) not void; restrictions directed against undermining security of State, within Article 19(2). Romesh Thapar and Brij Bhushan not applicable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Articles 19(1)(a), 19(2); Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras; Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi

respondent_arguments.text: Leaflet did not contain words under section 4(1).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, s.4(1)

respondent_arguments.text: Section 4(1)(a) inconsistent with Article 19(1), void under Article 13.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Articles 19(1), 13; Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras; Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi

respondent_arguments.text: Amendment to Article 19(2) repugnant to Article 20.

court_reasoning.text: Romesh Thapar and Brij Bhushan deal with wider public order restrictions, not specific incitement to violence under s.4(1)(a) which undermines State security.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section 4(1)(a) within Article 19(2) as it targets incitement to violent crimes like murder.

court_reasoning.text: Pamphlet is high-flown Bengali with demagogic claptrap, abstract propositions, no specific appeal or connection to agitation; no tendency to incite violence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Document read as whole has no effect on educated readers; empty slogans, poetic flourish.

court_reasoning.text: Consider writing as whole, not isolated passages; effect on ordinary reader in normal circumstances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence of exceptional circumstances like excited mob.

court_reasoning.text: Amendment to Article 19(2) not violative of Article 20; no retrospective criminalization.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act was law in 1949; no conviction involved.

holdings.text: Pamphlet does not fall within section 4(1)(a).

precedents_cited.case_name: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Deals with wider public order restrictions under Madras Act, not specific incitement to violence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar to Romesh Thapar; not applicable to s.4(1)(a).

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhagwati Charan Shukla v. Government of C.P. Berar
precedents_cited.relevance: Extravagant language in pamphlets does not incite violence in normal circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Badri Narain v. Chief Secretary, Bihar Government
precedents_cited.relevance: Poem had specific appeal to laborers; unlike abstract pamphlet here.
Words create no impression on reasonable reader; principle applies to s.4(1)(a).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Press (Emergency Powers) Act, 1931
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for security demand and challenge; s.4(1)(a) held constitutional but not attracted.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Freedom of speech restrictions valid if for State security; amendment to Art.19(2) retrospective but not violative of Art.20.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as High Court erred on constitutionality of s.4(1)(a) but correctly held pamphlet not within its mischief; no order as to costs.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court order setting aside security demand upheld.

key_quotes.text: "It is plain that speeches or expressions... which incite to or encourage the commission of violent crimes, such as murder, cannot but be matters which would undermine the security of the State and come within the ambit of a law sanctioned by article 19(2)."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The document is written in high-flown Bengali language and contains a good deal of demagogic claptrap with some pretence to poetic flourish."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Describes nature of pamphlet, explaining why no incitement.

key_quotes.text: "Writings of this character... neither excite nor have the tendency to excite any person... They will necessarily be educated people. Such writings leave their readers cold."
key_quotes.speaker: court
